alert.note: Alert for Broward; Collier; Glades; Hendry; Mainland Monroe; Miami-Dade; Palm Beach (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 12 at 2:00PM EST by NWS Miami
info.description: ...Flood Watch Possible For Portions Of South Florida Late This Week Into This Weekend... The long range models are still showing a stationary front moving northward from the Florida Straits into South Florida late this week, as high pressure slowly moves eastward over the Southeastern United States. By this weekend, a low pressure system will start to form over the Central Gulf of Mexico and move northeast into the Southeastern United States. This system will bring a slowly moving warm front across South Florida early this weekend, with a cold front moving southward through the region by late this weekend. This weather pattern will allow for a southwest steering flow to set up over South Florida late this week into this weekend, which will bring deep tropical moisture into the area from the Southern Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea. At the same time, the surface winds will be east to northeast late this week, before going south to southwest this weekend ahead of the cold front over South Florida. These two sources of moisture will allow for the PWAT values to increase to around 2 inches, which is near the maximum for this time of year over South Florida. Therefore, heavy rainfall is starting to look more likely for South Florida late this week into this weekend, especially over the east coast metro. Total rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches are possible over South Florida from late this week into this weekend, with the higher end of that range over the east coast metro. Rainfall amounts could even be higher where any heavy rainfall sets up due to training of showers and thunderstorms over the same area. We will continue to monitor the heavy rainfall potential for South Florida, and a Flood Watch may be needed for portions of the area from later this week into this weekend.
